trans-unit.source: Loaders allow more power in the JavaScript ecosystem through preprocessing functions (loaders). Users now have more flexibility to include fine-grained logic such as compression, packaging, language translations and more.
trans-unit.target: Los cargadores permiten más potencia en el ecosistema de JavaScript a través de funciones de preprocesamiento (cargadores). Los usuarios ahora tienen más flexibilidad para incluir lógica detallada, como compresión, empaquetado, traducciones de idiomas y más .

trans-unit.source: Loaders are always called from right to left. There are some instances where the loader only cares about the metadata behind a request and can ignore the results of the previous loader. The pitch method on loaders is called from left to right before the loaders are actually executed (from right to left).

Loaders are always called from right to left. There are some instances where the loader only cares about the metadata behind a request and can ignore the results of the previous loader. The pitch method on loaders is called from left to right before the loaders are actually executed (from right to left). For the following use configuration:
trans-unit.target: Los cargadores siempre se llaman de derecha a izquierda. Hay algunos casos en los que el cargador solo se preocupa por los metadatos detrás de una solicitud y puede ignorar los resultados del cargador anterior. El método de pitch en los cargadores se llama de izquierda a derecha antes de que se ejecuten realmente los cargadores (de derecha a izquierda). Para la siguiente configuración de use :

trans-unit.source: Loaders are activated by using loadername! prefixes in require() statements, or are automatically applied via regex from your webpack configuration – see configuration.
trans-unit.target: ¡Los cargadores se activan usando loadername! prefijos en las declaraciones require() , o se aplican automáticamente a través de expresiones regulares desde la configuración de su paquete web; consulte la configuración .

trans-unit.source: Loaders are evaluated/executed from right to left (or from bottom to top). In the example below execution starts with sass-loader, continues with css-loader and finally ends with style-loader. See "Loader Features" for more information about loaders order.

Loaders are evaluated/executed from right to left. In the example below execution starts with sass-loader, continues with css-loader and finally ends with style-loader. See "Loader Features" for more information about loaders order.
trans-unit.target: Los cargadores se evalúan / ejecutan de derecha a izquierda. En el siguiente ejemplo, la ejecución comienza con sass-loader, continúa con css-loader y finalmente termina con style-loader. Consulte "Características del cargador" para obtener más información sobre el pedido de los cargadores.

trans-unit.source: Loaders are transformations that are applied on the source code of a module. They allow you to pre-process files as you import or “load” them. Thus, loaders are kind of like “tasks” in other build tools and provide a powerful way to handle front-end build steps. Loaders can transform files from a different language (like TypeScript) to JavaScript or inline images as data URLs. Loaders even allow you to do things like import CSS files directly from your JavaScript modules!
trans-unit.target: Los cargadores son transformaciones que se aplican al código fuente de un módulo. Le permiten preprocesar archivos a medida que los import a o los "carga". Por lo tanto, los cargadores son una especie de "tareas" en otras herramientas de compilación y proporcionan una forma poderosa de manejar los pasos de compilación del front-end. Los cargadores pueden transformar archivos de un lenguaje diferente (como TypeScript) a JavaScript o imágenes en línea como URL de datos. Los cargadores incluso le permiten hacer cosas como import ar archivos CSS directamente desde sus módulos JavaScript.

trans-unit.source: Loaders are transformations that are applied to the source code of a module. They allow you to pre-process files as you import or “load” them. Thus, loaders are kind of like “tasks” in other build tools and provide a powerful way to handle front-end build steps. Loaders can transform files from a different language (like TypeScript) to JavaScript or load inline images as data URLs. Loaders even allow you to do things like import CSS files directly from your JavaScript modules!

Loaders are transformations that are applied to the source code of a module. They are written as functions that accept source code as a parameter and return a new version of that code with transformations applied.
trans-unit.target: Los cargadores son transformaciones que se aplican al código fuente de un módulo.Se escriben como funciones que aceptan el código fuente como un parámetro y devuelven una nueva versión de ese código con las transformaciones aplicadas.

trans-unit.source: Loaders can be chained by passing multiple loaders, which will be applied from right to left (last to first configured).
trans-unit.target: Los cargadores pueden ser encadenados pasando varios cargadores,que se aplicarán de derecha a izquierda (del último al primero configurado).

trans-unit.source: Loaders can be chained. Each loader in the chain applies transformations to the processed resource. A chain is executed in reverse order. The first loader passes its result (resource with applied transformations) to the next one, and so forth. Finally, webpack expects JavaScript to be returned by the last loader in the chain.
trans-unit.target: Los cargadores pueden ser encadenados.Cada cargador de la cadena aplica transformaciones al recurso procesado.Una cadena se ejecuta en orden inverso.El primer cargador pasa su resultado (recurso con transformaciones aplicadas)al siguiente,y así sucesivamente.Finalmente,Webpack espera que el último cargador de la cadena devuelva el Javascript.

trans-unit.source: Loaders can be configured with an options object (using query parameters to set options is still supported but has been deprecated).
trans-unit.target: Los cargadores se pueden configurar con un objeto de options ( todavía se admite el uso de parámetros de query para establecer opciones, pero ha quedado obsoleto).

trans-unit.source: Loaders can be synchronous or asynchronous.
trans-unit.target: Los cargadores pueden ser síncronos o asíncronos.

trans-unit.source: Loaders can emit additional arbitrary files.
trans-unit.target: Los cargadores pueden emitir archivos arbitrarios adicionales.

trans-unit.source: Loaders cannot access the webpack options.
trans-unit.target: Los cargadores no pueden acceder a las opciones del webpack.

trans-unit.source: Loaders cannot emit files.
trans-unit.target: Los cargadores no pueden emitir archivos.

trans-unit.source: Loaders cannot use custom loader API (i. e. by plugins).
trans-unit.target: Los cargadores no pueden utilizar la API de cargadores personalizados (es decir,por medio de plugins).

trans-unit.source: Loaders follow the standard module resolution. In most cases it will be loaded from the module path (think npm install, node_modules).
Loaders follow the standard module resolution. In most cases it will be loaders from the module path (think npm install, node_modules).
trans-unit.target: Los cargadores siguen la resolución estándar del módulo . En la mayoría de los casos, serán cargadores de la ruta del módulo (piense en npm install , node_modules ).

trans-unit.source: Loaders may be added inline in requests and disabled via inline prefixes, which will impact the order in which they are "pitched" and executed. See Rule.enforce for more details.
Loaders may use this.getLogger('name') to get an independent logger with a child name. Loader path and processed file is still added.

Loaders may use special fallback logic for detecting logging support this.getLogger() ? this.getLogger() : console to provide a fallback when an older webpack version is used which does not support getLogger method.

Loaders provide a way to customize the output through their preprocessing functions. Users now have more flexibility to include fine-grained logic such as compression, packaging, language translations and more.
Loaders run in Node.js and can do everything that’s possible there.
trans-unit.target: Los cargadores se ejecutan en Node.js y pueden hacer todo lo posible allí.

trans-unit.source: Loaders should prefer to use this.getLogger() for logging which is a shortcut to compilation.getLogger() with loader path and processed file. This kind of logging is stored to the Stats and formatted accordingly. It can be filtered and exported by the webpack user.

Loaders were originally designed to also work as Babel transforms. Therefore if you write a loader that works for both, you can use this property to know if there is access to additional loaderContext and webpack features.
trans-unit.target: Los cargadores fueron diseñados originalmente para que funcionaran también cuando Babel se transforma.Por lo tanto,si escribes un cargador que funcione para ambos,puedes usar esta propiedad para saber si hay acceso a características adicionales de loaderContext y webpack.

trans-unit.source: Loaders were originally designed to also work as Babel transforms. Therefore, if you write a loader that works for both, you can use this property to know if there is access to additional loaderContext and webpack features.

Loaders were originally designed to work in synchronous loader pipelines, like Node.js (using enhanced-require), and asynchronous pipelines, like in webpack. However, since expensive synchronous computations are a bad idea in a single-threaded environment like Node.js, we advise making your loader asynchronous if possible. Synchronous loaders are ok if the amount of computation is trivial.

Loaders were originally designed to work in synchronous loader pipelines, like Node.js (using enhanced-require), and asynchronous pipelines, like in webpack. However, since expensive synchronous computations are a bad idea in a single-threaded environment like Node.js, we advise to make your loader asynchronously if possible. Synchronous loaders are ok if the amount of computation is trivial.
trans-unit.target: Los cargadores se diseñaron originalmente para trabajar en canalizaciones de cargadores síncronos, como Node.js (que usa un requisito mejorado ), y canalizaciones asíncronas, como en webpack. Sin embargo, dado que los costosos cálculos síncronos son una mala idea en un entorno de un solo subproceso como Node.js, le recomendamos que realice su cargador de forma asíncrona si es posible. Los cargadores síncronos están bien si la cantidad de cálculo es trivial.

trans-unit.source: Many applications share a common components library which could be built as a container with each component exposed. Each application consumes components from the components library container. Changes to the components library can be separately deployed without the need to re-deploy all applications. The application automatically uses the up-to-date version of the components library.
Many frameworks and libraries have their own recommendations on how this should be accomplished within their methodologies. Here are a few examples:

trans-unit.source: Many libraries will key off the process.env.NODE_ENV variable to determine what should be included in the library. For example, when process.env.NODE_ENV is not set to 'production' some libraries may add additional logging and testing to make debugging easier. However, with process.env.NODE_ENV set to 'production' they might drop or add significant portions of code to optimize how things run for your actual users. Since webpack v4, specifying mode automatically configures DefinePlugin for you:

Many libraries will key off the process.env.NODE_ENV variable to determine what should be included in the library. For example, when not in production some libraries may add additional logging and testing to make debugging easier. However, with process.env.NODE_ENV === 'production' they might drop or add significant portions of code to optimize how things run for your actual users. Since webpack v4, specifying mode automatically configures DefinePlugin for you:
trans-unit.target: Muchas bibliotecas eliminarán la variable process.env.NODE_ENV para determinar qué se debe incluir en la biblioteca. Por ejemplo, cuando no están en producción, algunas bibliotecas pueden agregar registros y pruebas adicionales para facilitar la depuración. Sin embargo, con process.env.NODE_ENV === 'production' , podrían eliminar o agregar porciones significativas de código para optimizar cómo funcionan las cosas para sus usuarios reales. Desde webpack v4, especificar el mode configura automáticamente DefinePlugin para usted:

trans-unit.source: Node.js Versions 8.9.10-9.11.1

Node.js allows to detection production/development mode at runtime via process.env.NODE_ENV, so we use that as fallback in Node.js. Sync conditional importing ESM is not possible and we don't want to load the package twice, so we have to use CommonJs for the runtime detection.

Node.js established a way of explicitly setting the module type of files by using a property in the package.json. Setting "type": "module" in a package.json does force all files below this package.json to be ECMAScript Modules. Setting "type": "commonjs" will instead force them to be CommonJS Modules.

Node.js has supported modular programming almost since its inception. On the web, however, support for modules has been slow to arrive. Multiple tools exist that support modular JavaScript on the web, with a variety of benefits and limitations. webpack builds on lessons learned from these systems and applies the concept of modules to any file in your project.
trans-unit.target: Node.js ha admitido la programación modular casi desde sus inicios. En la web, sin embargo, el soporte para módulos ha tardado en llegar. Existen varias herramientas que admiten JavaScript modular en la web, con una variedad de beneficios y limitaciones. webpack se basa en las lecciones aprendidas de estos sistemas y aplica el concepto de módulos a cualquier archivo de su proyecto.

Esto aumenta el tamaño y puede invalidar el paquete cuando cambia el valor del marcador de posición para cualquier fragmento.

trans-unit.source: Note that this approach prioritizes correctness over bundle size. To be safe and robust, polyfills/shims must run before all other code, and thus either need to load synchronously, or, all app code needs to load after all polyfills/shims load. There are many misconceptions in the community, as well, that modern browsers "don't need" polyfills, or that polyfills/shims merely serve to add missing features - in fact, they often repair broken implementations, even in the most modern of browsers. The best practice thus remains to unconditionally and synchronously load all polyfills/shims, despite the bundle size cost this incurs.

trans-unit.source: Note that webpack needs to generate a unique module identifier from the resource and all loaders including options. It tries to do this with a JSON.stringify of the options object. This is fine in 99.9% of cases, but may be not unique if you apply the same loaders with different options to the resource and the options have some stringified values.
trans-unit.target: Tenga en cuenta que el paquete web debe generar un identificador de módulo único a partir del recurso y todos los cargadores, incluidas las opciones. Intenta hacer esto con un JSON.stringify del objeto de opciones. Esto está bien en el 99,9% de los casos, pero puede no ser único si aplica los mismos cargadores con diferentes opciones al recurso y las opciones tienen algunos valores en cadena.

trans-unit.source: Note that webpack will not alter any code other than import and export statements. If you are using other ES2015 features, make sure to use a transpiler such as Babel or Bublé via webpack's loader system.
trans-unit.target: Tenga en cuenta que el paquete web no alterará ningún código que no sean declaraciones de import ación y export ación . Si está utilizando otras funciones de ES2015 , asegúrese de utilizar un transpilador como Babel o Bublé a través del sistema de carga de webpack .

trans-unit.source: Note that when using import() on ES6 modules you must reference the .default property as it's the actual module object that will be returned when the promise is resolved.
trans-unit.target: Tenga en cuenta que cuando utilice import() en módulos ES6, debe hacer referencia a la propiedad .default , ya que es el objeto del module real que se devolverá cuando se resuelva la promesa.

trans-unit.source: Note that when using sass (Dart Sass), synchronous compilation is twice as fast as asynchronous compilation by default, due to the overhead of asynchronous callbacks. To avoid this overhead, you can use the fibers package to call asynchronous importers from the synchronous code path.

Note that when using Dart Sass, synchronous compilation is twice as fast as asynchronous compilation by default, due to the overhead of asynchronous callbacks. To avoid this overhead, you can use the fibers package to call asynchronous importers from the synchronous code path. To enable this, pass the Fiber class to the fiber option:
trans-unit.target: Tenga en cuenta que al usar Dart Sass, la compilación sincrónica es dos veces más rápida que la compilación asincrónica de forma predeterminada, debido a la sobrecarga de las devoluciones de llamada asincrónicas. Para evitar esta sobrecarga, puede utilizar el paquete de fibers para llamar a importadores asíncronos desde la ruta del código síncrono. Para habilitar esto, pase la clase de Fiber a la opción de fiber :

trans-unit.source: Notice anything different about dist/bundle.js? Clearly the whole bundle is now minified and mangled, but, if you look carefully, you won't see the square function included but will see a mangled version of the cube function (function r(e){return e*e*e}n.a=r). With minification and tree shaking our bundle is now a few bytes smaller! While that may not seem like much in this contrived example, tree shaking can yield a significant decrease in bundle size when working on larger applications with complex dependency trees.
trans-unit.target: ¿Notas algo diferente sobre dist/bundle.js ? Claramente, todo el paquete ahora está reducido y destrozado, pero, si miras con atención, no verás la función square incluida, pero verás una versión destrozada de la función cube ( function r(e){return e*e*e}n.a=r ). ¡Con la minificación y la agitación de árboles, nuestro paquete ahora es unos bytes más pequeño! Si bien eso puede no parecer mucho en este ejemplo artificial, la agitación de árboles puede producir una disminución significativa en el tamaño del paquete cuando se trabaja en aplicaciones más grandes con árboles de dependencia complejos.

trans-unit.source: Notice anything different about dist/bundle.js? Clearly the whole bundle is now minified and mangled, but, if you look carefully, you won't see the square function included but will see a mangled version of the cube function (function r(e){return e*e*e}n.a=r). With minification and tree shaking, our bundle is now a few bytes smaller! While that may not seem like much in this contrived example, tree shaking can yield a significant decrease in bundle size when working on larger applications with complex dependency trees.
Notice that many array configurations allow to reference the default value via "...".

Notice that throughout the configuration we use Node's built-in path module and prefix it with the __dirname global. This prevents file path issues between operating systems and allows relative paths to work as expected. See this section for more info on POSIX vs. Windows paths.
trans-unit.target: Tenga en cuenta que a lo largo de la configuración usamos el módulo de ruta incorporado de Node y lo prefijo con el __dirname global. Esto evita problemas de rutas de archivo entre sistemas operativos y permite que las rutas relativas funcionen como se esperaba. Consulte esta sección para obtener más información sobre las rutas POSIX frente a Windows.

When using the css-loader, as shown above, a similar process will occur for url('./my-image.png') within your CSS. The loader will recognize this is a local file, and replace the './my-image.png' path with the final path to the image in your output directory. The html-loader handles <img src="./my-image.png" /> in the same manner.

El cargador reconocerá que se trata de un archivo local y reemplazará la './my-image.png' con la ruta final a la imagen en su directorio de output . El cargador html maneja <img src="./my-image.png" /> de la misma manera.

trans-unit.source: Often webpack users use npm scripts as their task runner. This is a good starting point. Cross-platform support can become a problem, but there are several workarounds for that. Many, if not most users, get by with simple npm scripts and various levels of webpack configuration and tooling.
trans-unit.target: A menudo, los usuarios de paquetes web utilizan scripts npm como ejecutor de tareas. Este es un buen punto de partida. El soporte multiplataforma puede convertirse en un problema, pero existen varias soluciones para eso. Muchos, si no la mayoría de los usuarios, se las arreglan con simples scripts npm y varios niveles de configuración y herramientas de paquetes web.

trans-unit.source: Old school Task Runners and even Google Closure Compiler requires you to manually declare all dependencies upfront. While bundlers like webpack automatically builds and infer your dependency graph based on what is imported and exported. This along with other plugins and loaders make for a great developer experience.

trans-unit.source: On some machines Vim is preconfigured with the backupcopy option set to auto. This could potentially cause problems with the system's file watching mechanism. Switching this option to yes will make sure a copy of the file is made and the original one overwritten on save.

Esto podría causar problemas con el mecanismo de vigilancia de archivos del sistema. Si cambia esta opción a yes se asegurará de que se haga una copia del archivo y se sobrescriba el original al guardar.

trans-unit.source: Once your application hits the browser in the form of index.html file, some bundles and a variety of other assets required by your application must be loaded and linked somehow. That /src directory you meticulously laid out is now bundled, minified and maybe even split into smaller chunks for lazy-loading by webpack's optimization. So how does webpack manage the interaction between all of your required modules? This is where the manifest data comes in...
One approach is to have a "bootstrap" step in your application that would first override the default globals before your application:

trans-unit.source: One chunk group with the main name created (main is the default name for an entry point). This chunk group contains ./index.js module. As the parser handles imports inside ./index.js new modules are added into this chunk.

One of the coolest webpack features is that you can also include any other type of file, besides JavaScript, for which there is a loader or built-in Asset Modules support. This means that the same benefits listed above for JavaScript (e.g. explicit dependencies) can be applied to everything used in building a website or web app. Let's start with CSS, as you may already be familiar with that setup.

One of the coolest webpack features is that you can also include any other type of file, besides JavaScript, for which there is a loader. This means that the same benefits listed above for JavaScript (e.g. explicit dependencies) can be applied to everything used in building a website or web app. Let's start with CSS, as you may already be familiar with that setup.
trans-unit.target: Una de las características más interesantes del paquete web es que también puede incluir cualquier otro tipo de archivo , además de JavaScript, para el que hay un cargador. Esto significa que los mismos beneficios enumerados anteriormente para JavaScript (por ejemplo, dependencias explícitas) se pueden aplicar a todo lo que se utiliza en la creación de un sitio web o una aplicación web. Comencemos con CSS, ya que es posible que ya esté familiarizado con esa configuración.

trans-unit.source: Plugins are a key piece of the webpack ecosystem and provide the community with a powerful way to tap into webpack's compilation process. A plugin is able to hook into key events that are fired throughout each compilation. Every step of the way, the plugin will have full access to the compiler and, when applicable, the current compilation.
trans-unit.target: Los complementos son una pieza clave del ecosistema de paquetes web y brindan a la comunidad una forma poderosa de aprovechar el proceso de compilación de paquetes web. Un complemento puede conectarse a eventos clave que se activan a lo largo de cada compilación. En cada paso del camino, el complemento tendrá acceso completo al compiler y, cuando corresponda, a la compilation actual .

trans-unit.source: Plugins can affect logging capturing and display level
Plugins can give loaders more features.
trans-unit.target: Los plugins pueden dar a los cargadores más características.

trans-unit.source: Plugins can report progress via ProgressPlugin, which prints progress messages to stderr by default. In order to enable progress reporting, pass a --progress argument when running the webpack CLI.

Plugins may use special fallback logic for detecting logging support compilation.getLogger ? compilation.getLogger('PluginName') : console to provide a fallback for cases when an older webpack version is used which does not support getLogger method on compilation object.

Plugins may use the compiler.getInfrastructureLogger('PluginName') for logging. Using infrastructure logging is not stored in the Stats and therefore not formatted. It's usually logged to the console/dashboard/GUI directly. It can be filtered by the user.
Plugins should prefer to use compilation.getLogger('PluginName') for logging. This kind of logging is stored in the Stats and formatted accordingly. It can be filtered and exported by the user.
Plugins, which add entry chunks to the compilation.
trans-unit.target: Plugins,que añaden trozos de entrada a la compilación.

Prior to webpack 5 it was common to use:

Prior to webpack, front-end developers would use tools like grunt and gulp to process these assets and move them from their /src folder into their /dist or /build directory. The same idea was used for JavaScript modules, but tools like webpack will dynamically bundle all dependencies (creating what's known as a dependency graph). This is great because every module now explicitly states its dependencies and we'll avoid bundling modules that aren't in use.

Prior to webpack, front-end developers would use tools like grunt and gulp to process these assets and move them from their /src folder into their /dist or /build directory. The same idea was used for JavaScript modules, but tools like webpack will dynamically bundle all dependencies (creating what's known as a dependency graph). This is great because every module now explicitly states its dependencies and we'll avoid bundling modules that aren't in use.
trans-unit.target: Antes del paquete web, los desarrolladores front-end usaban herramientas como grunt y gulp para procesar estos activos y moverlos de su carpeta /src a su directorio /dist o /build . Se utilizó la misma idea para los módulos de JavaScript, pero herramientas como el paquete web agruparán dinámicamente todas las dependencias (creando lo que se conoce como un gráfico de dependencias ). Esto es genial porque cada módulo ahora establece explícitamente sus dependencias y evitaremos agrupar módulos que no estén en uso.

trans-unit.source: Progressive Web Applications (or PWAs) are web apps that deliver an experience similar to native applications. There are many things that can contribute to that. Of these, the most significant is the ability for an app to be able to function when offline. This is achieved through the use of a web technology called Service Workers.
trans-unit.target: Las aplicaciones web progresivas (o PWA) son aplicaciones web que brindan una experiencia similar a las aplicaciones nativas. Hay muchas cosas que pueden contribuir a eso. De estos, el más significativo es la capacidad de una aplicación para funcionar sin conexión . Esto se logra mediante el uso de una tecnología web llamada Service Workers .

trans-unit.source: Putting the content of helpers into each chunk will result into its code being downloaded twice. By using a separate chunk this will only happen once. We pay the cost of an additional request, which could be considered a tradeoff. That's why there is a minimum size of 30kb.
trans-unit.target: Si coloca el contenido de los helpers en cada fragmento, su código se descargará dos veces. Al usar un fragmento separado, esto solo sucederá una vez. Pagamos el costo de una solicitud adicional, que podría considerarse una compensación. Por eso hay un tamaño mínimo de 30 kb.

trans-unit.source: Readable ids for better debugging.

Recently, ts-loader has started to consume the internal TypeScript watch mode APIs which dramatically decreases the number of modules to be rebuilt on each iteration. This experimentalWatchApi shares the same logic as the normal TypeScript watch mode itself and is quite stable for development use. Turn on transpileOnly as well for truly fast incremental builds.
trans-unit.target: Recientemente, ts-loader ha comenzado a consumir las API internas del modo de vigilancia de TypeScript, lo que reduce drásticamente la cantidad de módulos que se reconstruirán en cada iteración. Este experimentalWatchApi comparte la misma lógica que el modo de reloj normal de TypeScript y es bastante estable para su uso en desarrollo. Activa transpileOnly también para compilaciones incrementales realmente rápidas.

trans-unit.source: Resolvers are created using the enhanced-resolve package. The Resolver class extends the tapable class and uses tapable to provide a few hooks. The enhanced-resolve package can be used directly to create new resolvers, however any compiler instance has a few resolver instances that can be tapped into.
trans-unit.target: enhanced-resolve se crean utilizando el paquete de resolución mejorada . La clase Resolver extiende la clase tapable y usa tapable para proporcionar algunos ganchos. El paquete de enhanced-resolve se puede usar directamente para crear nuevos resolutores, sin embargo, cualquier instancia de compiler tiene algunas instancias de resolutor que se pueden aprovechar.

trans-unit.source: Resolves the given request to a module, applies all configured loaders and calls back with the generated source, the sourceMap and the module instance (usually an instance of NormalModule). Use this function if you need to know the source code of another module to generate the result.
trans-unit.target: Resuelve la solicitud dada a un módulo, aplica todos los cargadores configurados y devuelve las llamadas con la fuente generada, el sourceMap y la instancia del módulo (generalmente una instancia de NormalModule ). Utilice esta función si necesita conocer el código fuente de otro módulo para generar el resultado.

trans-unit.source: Scope hoisting is specifically a feature made possible by ECMAScript Module syntax. Because of this webpack may fallback to normal bundling based on what kind of modules you are using, and other conditions.
trans-unit.target: La elevación del osciloscopio es específicamente una característica posible gracias a la sintaxis del módulo ECMAScript. Debido a que este paquete web puede recurrir a la agrupación normal en función del tipo de módulos que esté utilizando y otras condiciones .
